title: Artificial Intelligence, Domain AI Readiness, and Firm Productivity
affiliations: Cheung Kong Graduate School of Business, University of Texas at Dallas and Cheung Kong Graduate School of Business

detail.title: Artificial Intelligence, Domain AI Readiness, and Firm Productivity
detail.abstract: Although Artificial Intelligence (AI) holds great promise for enhancing innovation and productivity, many firms struggle to realize its benefits. We investigate why some firms and industry succeed with AI while others do not, focusing on the degree to which an industrial domain is technologically integrated with AI as domain AI readiness, which we termed "domain AI readiness". Using panel data on Chinese listed firms from 2016 to 2022, we examine how the interaction between firm-level AI capabilities and domain AI readiness affects firm performance. We create a novel constructs from patent data and measure domain AI readiness of a specific domain based on the co-occurrence of four-digit International Patent Classification (IPC4) codes of AI with the specific domain across all patents in that domain. Our findings reveal a strong complementarity: AI capabilities yield greater productivity and innovation gains when deployed in domains with higher AI readiness, whereas benefits are limited in domains that are technologically unprepared or already obsolete. These results remain robust when using local AI policy initiatives as instrumental variables. Further analysis shows that this complementarity is driven by external advances in domain-AI integration, rather than firms' own strategic pivots. Time-series analysis of IPC4 co-occurrence patterns further suggests that improvements in domain AI readiness stem primarily from the academic advancements of AI in specific domains.

title: A Roadmap for Agentic AI in Financial Services Industry
affiliations: Independent, Independent, Independent, Independent and Independent

detail.title: A Roadmap for Agentic AI in Financial Services Industry
detail.abstract: The financial sector is undergoing a profound shift, supported by advances in Artificial Intelligence (AI). While AI has long been used for tasks like fraud detection and risk assessment, the arrival of Agentic AI marks a new era. Powered by Large Language Models (LLMs), these systems can operate independently, learn in real-time, and manage complex tasks, acting more like a team member than a simple tool. However, deploying such powerful technology in the highly regulated world of finance requires a careful and structured approach. This paper introduces the ADAPT framework (Assess, Design, Assemble, Pilot, Transform) a practical guide for financial institutions. ADAPT breaks down the journey into five key stages-from setting strategic goals and navigating regulations to building the right teams, testing in controlled environments, and scaling innovations with strong governance. By following this roadmap, our framework helps ensure that the adoption of Agentic AI is not only innovative but also responsible, secure, and compliant, allowing firms to confidently unlock the full potential of this groundbreaking technology.

title: Patient-Directed Data Capture for Clinical Research: A Pilot Study Testing Two Platforms
affiliations: Duke University - Duke Clinical Research Institute, Duke University - Duke Clinical Research Institute, Duke University - School of Medicine, Duke University - Duke Clinical Research Institute, Duke University - Duke Clinical Research Institute, Duke University - Duke Clinical Research Institute and Duke University - Duke Clinical Research Institute

detail.title: Patient-Directed Data Capture for Clinical Research: A Pilot Study Testing Two Platforms
detail.abstract: BackgroundPatient-directed data capture enables individuals to access and share their electronic health record (EHR) data, potentially supporting patient engagement while also reducing data fragmentation. Although many vendors offer patient-directed data capture, little is known about how feasible or reliable these approaches are in practice.MethodsWe conducted a single-site pilot study to evaluate the feasibility of different patient-directed data capture platforms. Thirty-four participants hospitalized for heart failure at Duke Health participated; 26 engaged with Hugo Health, which used application programming interfaces (APIs) to retrieve data, and 17 with Datavant, which relied on records requests. Nine participants used both platforms.ResultsData retrieval success varied by method: the API approach retrieved 88% of requested records, while the records request approach retrieved 20%. Concordance with institutional data was observed for 11 of 24 (46%) outcomes using APIs and 14 of 24 (58%) using records requests. The API approach identified nine additional outcomes not recorded in the institutional EHR, reflecting integration of external system data, while records requests identified three additional outcomes. Only 22% of participants reported willingness to reuse their assigned vendor, and 33% required onboarding support. Technical challenges included the need to process JavaScript Object Notation (JSON) files (API approach) and to manually abstract documents from PDF files (records request approach).ConclusionsOne platform retrieved records across multiple health systems and identified additional outcomes; the other achieved greater concordance with local records. Improved retrieval workflows, cross-system integration, and user-friendly data formats are needed to support scalable, patient-centered research.

detail.abstract: To make deliberate progress in understanding the economic transformation driven by AI, we need an analytical economic framework-a kind of economic world model-that goes deeper than traditional economics. Existing approaches are fragmented: they isolate variables such as productivity or employment and often focus on narrow use cases. Empirical studies are also unreliable because AI adoption is uneven and the technology is evolving rapidly. Most importantly, standard economic models largely ignore the role of information, making them ill-suited to explain the systemic changes triggered by a disruptive information technology such as AI. We propose the NanoEconomic eXplanation & eXploration Framework (NEXX-Frame) as such an analytical framework to address this gap. Operating at the "atomic" level of economic activity-the individual decisions and actions that make up all processes-it uses idealized variables as templates to model real-world agents and their specific information use. This allows us to trace how marginal changes in information supply (∆Info) first alter individual processes and then propagate through entire systems. Our analysis reveals the transmission mechanisms through which AI-enabled ∆Info reshapes production, consumption, and markets. These effects unfold in multiple waves and include second-and higher-order consequences invisible to traditional models. While difficult to validate empirically, this framework offers a rigorous basis-an economic world model serving as a playground for simulation and thought experiments. It enables researchers and policymakers alike to explore the possible outcomes of AI adoption, and it offers every single economic agent a sharper lens to understand and shape their own decisions and actions.

title: Reflections of Global Supply Chains in Mirror Trade Data
affiliations: University of Southampton and Queen Mary University of London - School of Business and Management

detail.title: Reflections of Global Supply Chains in Mirror Trade Data
detail.abstract: Mirror trade data is the official statistics of imports and exports for the same commodity as reported separately by pairs of trade partners. In this paper, we utilize mirror trade data from United Nations Commodity Trade Statistics Database (UN Comtrade) to analyze global logistics and supply chains. In particular, we use the data to estimate: (1) Trade lead times, i.e., the length of time between the recording of the export at the source end and the corresponding import at the destination end, with international transport as the main component, and (2) Transshipment within transit blocs, wherein imports or exports to the destination country pass through another country within a customs-bonded transit bloc. Our estimates of trade lead time provide insights into the modes of transport and systematic shifts in lead times at both individual commodity and aggregate levels. The transshipment model identifies indirect sources of imports and enables reconstructing trade flow networks. Using the case study of UK and Western Europe imports from from Asia, we estimate the changes in aggregate trade lead times between 2018 and 2023, measure the Rotterdam Effect, and explore the impact of Brexit on transshipment patterns. We provide a practical tool for reducing import-export discrepancy in mirror trade data and tracking international trade lead times, key for trade and supply chain analysts. We show, for instance, the trade lead times have increased since 2022, consistent with proprietary data, which has clear implications for inventory management and supply chain risk management.

title: Heterogeneous Intermediaries in the Transmission of Central Bank Corporate Bond Purchases
affiliations: European Central Bank (ECB) and Stanford University

detail.title: Heterogeneous Intermediaries in the Transmission of Central Bank Corporate Bond Purchases
detail.abstract: This paper studies the role of financial intermediaries in the transmission of central bank corporate bond purchases to bond yields. Contrary to standard expectations, we find that mutual funds—typically viewed as price-elastic investors—amplify, rather than dampen, the effects of these interventions on bond spreads. Following the ECB’s corporate bond purchase announcements in 2016 and 2020, bonds predominantly held by mutual funds experienced significantly larger and more persistent declines in spreads compared to those held by price-inelastic investors such as insurance companies, even after controlling for a broad set of bond characteristics. Drawing on additional empirical evidence and an equilibrium asset pricing model, we show that the state-contingent nature of the policy reduces perceived market risk for procyclical investors like mutualfunds, thereby boosting demand and compressing risk premia.

title: Exploring the Role of Development Finance Institutions in Developing Nations
affiliations: Oxford Institute for Economic Studies

detail.title: Exploring the Role of Development Finance Institutions in Developing Nations
detail.abstract: State-sponsored Development Finance Institutions (DFIs) have emerged as pivotal actors in advancing private sector initiatives within developing regions. This paper offers an integrated review of both scholarly works and grey literature to deliver a nuanced and in-depth exploration of DFIs. The discussion is organised around five principal themes: the foundational justification for DFIs; their strategic and institutional frameworks; the tools and financial mechanisms they employ; their economic performance; and their developmental influence on both project-level stakeholders and wider communities. By shedding light on well-documented findings as well as persisting knowledge voids, this study provides valuable insights for decision-makers, field practitioners, and academic researchers alike. The conclusion outlines prospective areas for further inquiry, aiming to resolve lingering ambiguities and contribute meaningfully to ongoing debates about the evolving role of DFIs in the domain of development finance.

title: Digital Recruitment Platforms and Unemployment in Morocco: Evidence from an Impact Assessment
affiliations: University Mohammed V of Rabat

detail.title: Digital Recruitment Platforms and Unemployment in Morocco: Evidence from an Impact Assessment
detail.abstract: This study investigates the impact of digital platforms for job matching on the employment outcomes of young graduates in Morocco. Using a Difference-inDifferences (DiD) methodology with data from the ANAPEC database for 2021-2024, the study evaluates the effectiveness of these platforms in improving job placement and reducing unemployment. The findings indicate that digital platforms have a significant positive impact on youth employment, particularly in terms of reducing the time-to-employment and improving the quality of job matches. However, regional disparities in digital infrastructure and varying levels of digital literacy highlight the need for targeted policy interventions to ensure equitable access to these platforms. The results suggest that while digital job matching tools are a promising solution to youth unemployment, they should be part of a broader, multi-faceted approach that includes strengthening traditional labor market institutions, investing in digital literacy, and addressing socioeconomic factors affecting youth employment. This study contributes to understanding the role of digital platforms in labor market dynamics and provides recommendations for policymakers in Morocco and similar economies.

title: Broadband Saves Lives: The Impact of Broadband on Youth Suicide Rates
affiliations: Digital Markets Initiative

detail.title: Broadband Saves Lives: The Impact of Broadband on Youth Suicide Rates
detail.abstract: I examine the impact of broadband adoption on youth (aged 15 to 24) suicide death rates at the U.S. state level. I find that in general, there is a negative correlation between broadband connections (mobile and fixed) and suicide death rate among states. To address the issue of causality, I used the population-weighted average county minimum distance to a major river or coastline and the weighted average county length of railroads in 1870 as instruments for broadband connections per state population. Counties’ ease of access to major rivers or coastline, as well as availability of railroad tracks were significant determinants for whether a county received a telephone line in the early twentieth century, and as technology persists, still has an impact on broadband adoption today. The two-stage least squares results show that, in 2023, for a one standard deviation increase in the number of broadband connections over the population (0.06), the crude rate of suicide deaths per 10,000 target residents declined by 3.77. The effect is significant at the 99% confidence level.

title: Forecasting the Path of SNAP Spending Using State-Level Panel Data Models
affiliations: Texas A&M University (TAMU), Central Texas, Texas A&M University (TAMU), Central Texas, Texas A&M University (TAMU), Central Texas, Texas A&M University (TAMU), Central Texas and United States Department of Agriculture, Fort Collins

detail.title: Forecasting the Path of SNAP Spending Using State-Level Panel Data Models
detail.abstract: Forecasting total Supplemental Nutrition Assistance Program (SNAP) spending is essential for effective budget planning and policy design. We develop panel econometric forecasting models that predict total SNAP spending using a bottom-up approach that models its key components-enrollment, monthly benefits, and administrative expenses-at the state level and aggregates them to the national level. This structure supports conditional forecasts under counterfactual state-level economic and policy conditions and can improve forecast accuracy by leveraging cross-state variation. Our modeling approach integrates economic theory and empirical insights with a systematic model selection procedure that searches over a large universe of candidate forecasting specifications and selects those with the most accurate forecasts for each component, as measured by root mean squared forecast error. We find that more parsimonious specifications consistently yield more accurate forecasts than more complex alternatives across all components. Importantly, we show that for the enrollment component, simpler one-way state fixed effects models with deterministic trends outperform the two-way fixed effects estimator widely used in studies of SNAP enrollment cyclicality. We also find that, for enrollment, more flexible common factor models that account for cross-state dependencies can improve forecast accuracy relative to simpler approaches, but the gains are limited due to the already strong performance of our top models. We provide practical guidance for applying our models to long-term baseline and conditional forecasts.

title: Shifting Hours: Time Allocation and Gender Inequality in India 1999-2019
affiliations: Oklahoma State University - Stillwater and Oklahoma State University

detail.title: Shifting Hours: Time Allocation and Gender Inequality in India 1999-2019
detail.abstract: Using two waves of Time Use Survey (1998-99 and 2019) from six states of India, we examine shifts in time allocation across leisure, employment, childcare, and domestic work. A Blinder-Oaxaca decomposition shows that the increase in leisure time and the decrease in employment time is driven more by changes in behavior within demographic groups than by changes in population composition. Women have also reduced time spent in domestic work, reallocating some of it to leisure. Applying the Juhn-Murphy-Pierce framework, we uncover contrasting distributional patterns: the inequality of leisure time, captured by the 90-10 percentile gap, has widened sharply, driven almost entirely by unobservable factors. Employment time inequality has increased among men but declined among women; inequality in domestic work has also narrowed for women. However, domestic work remains overwhelmingly the domain of women in both urban and rural areas, underscoring the persistence of gendered constraints in time allocation.

title: The Essence of an Integrated Management System (IMS): Overcoming Silos through the ISO Harmonized Structure and Designing a Management OS with ISO 9001 at the Core

detail.abstract: Many organizations operate multiple management systems (MSs)-e.g., ISO 9001 (quality), ISO 14001 (environment), and ISO 45001 (occupational health and safety)-yet their operation often devolves into siloing oriented toward obtaining individual certifications. Such siloing not only produces inefficiencies (duplicated documentation, fragmented roles) but also impedes an integrated response to enterprise-wide risks and opportunities, thereby undermining the potential contribution of MSs to management. This paper offers a remedy to this problem. First, it argues that Annex SL / the ISO Harmonized Structure (hereafter, HLS) functions as a common language and blueprint for integration. Building on this, it reconceptualizes a true Integrated Management System (IMS)-not as a mere aggregation of standards but as a Management Operating System (Management OS). As a concrete, practice-oriented model, the paper proposes positioning ISO 9001 as the core (backbone) of the IMS. Leveraging the strong coupling between Clause 8 (Operation) and real business processes, it shows how to "reinforce" that backbone with elements from other MSs (e.g., ISO 14001, ISO 45001). The aim is to provide a theoretical and practical guide to move beyond formalistic operation and elevate MSs into bona fide managerial tools.

title: Custom to Code: A Doctrine of Functional Norms for Emergent Agent Practices
affiliations: Avyayam Holdings and Singapore Management University - Lee Kong Chian School of Business

detail.title: Custom to Code: A Doctrine of Functional Norms for Emergent Agent Practices

declarations.funderStatement: This research was supported by the Ministry of Education (MOE), Singapore, under its Academic Research Fund (AcRF) Tier 2 Grant, No. MOE-T2EP40221-0008.

detail.abstract: Agentic AI systems operating with autonomy generate emergent norms-transient, unwritten rules of interaction-in multi-agent environments like logistics networks and digital markets. These machine-generated regularities structure transactions and allocate risk, yet they fall into a legal blind spot. Existing doctrines for recognizing informal practices, such as the UCC's "usage of trade" or tort law's "custom," are ill-suited to the speed, opacity, and nonhuman nature of algorithmic behavior, creating a gap in contract, tort, and competition law. This Article proposes a doctrine of functional norms to fill that gap. It argues that an emergent regularity should be treated as legally operative when it functions as a norm in a transaction. To operationalize this standard, the Article develops a seven-factor test. A practice qualifies as a functional norm when it is: (1) foreseeable to affected parties; (2) regular within the relevant transactional window; (3) attributable to a legally responsible principal; (4) material to outcomes; (5) verifiable through contemporaneous digital records; (6) consistent with express contractual terms; and (7) cleared by a legality screen that bars recognition of anticompetitive or otherwise unlawful conduct. The doctrine provides a pliable yet principled framework. Recognized norms can be used to interpret agreements, fill contractual gaps, and serve as probative (but not dispositive) evidence of the standard of care. To render the doctrine administrable, the Article supplies an evidentiary toolkit for discovery, model contractual clauses for private ordering, and a model legislative provision. This approach equips the law to identify and regulate the rules that govern emerging algorithmic markets, balancing innovation with accountability.

title: Courts, Legislation and Delaware Corporate Law
affiliations: Tel Aviv University; Buchman Faculty of Law; Coller School of Management and Tel Aviv University - Buchmann Faculty of Law

detail.title: Courts, Legislation and Delaware Corporate Law
detail.abstract: Delaware is widely regarded as the global capital of corporate law and the leader in attracting incorporations. Its dominance is often attributed by legal scholars to its expert judiciary and reliance on judicial decision-making to develop corporate norms. Indeed, for decades, the prevailing view has been that legislation plays a minimal role in shaping corporate law. However, after two recent high-profile legislative responses to court decisions, questions regarding the appropriate scope of legislative intervention took center stage in corporate legal debates. This Article situates these recent debates within a broader perspective by examining the interplay between the courts and legislation in Delaware over nearly six decades. We analyze amendments to the Delaware General Corporation Law (DGCL) from 1967 to 2025 and uncover a consistent pattern of legislative responses to judicial decisions. These responses, we argue, address critical challenges inherent in Delaware's reliance on judge-made law, including the tension between norm-setting and insulating corporate insiders from out-of-pocket liability, the limitations of fiduciary-based adjudication, and other institutional constraints of the judiciary. The interplay between courts and legislation also allows Delaware to adapt to stakeholder pressures and mitigate the risk of federal intervention or other threats to Delaware's dominance. However, too frequent or openly contentious legislative overrides could undermine Delaware's dominance by threatening judicial independence and raising concerns about the effect of interest groups on Delaware's corporate law. Uncovering the pattern of legislative responses raises important questions about the forces shaping Delaware's corporate law and the underlying interaction between its judiciary and legislative branches. This Article explores some of these questions and considers implications for future research.

title: Entry Deterrence with Public Signals: Revisiting the Chain-Store Paradox
affiliations: University of Bonn and Indiana University - Kelley School of Business - Department of Business Economics & Public Policy

detail.title: Entry Deterrence with Public Signals: Revisiting the Chain-Store Paradox
detail.abstract: We revisit the classic chain-store paradox by introducing a novel element: the arrival of exogenous, public signals about the incumbent's private type over time. As the horizon lengthens, two opposing forces come into play. On one hand, standard reputational incentives grow stronger; on the other, the increasing availability of information makes it more difficult to sustain a reputation. We fully characterize the conditions under which full deterrence arises in the infinite-horizon limit.

title: Compassionate Communication: Are Your Words Building Walls or Bridges?
affiliations: City University of New York (CUNY) - Koppelman School of Business

detail.title: Compassionate Communication: Are Your Words Building Walls or Bridges?
detail.abstract: This paper explores the critical difference between violent and compassionate communication, using Marshall Rosenberg's Nonviolent Communication (NVC) framework as a guide for transforming conflict. Violent communication-characterized by blame, shame, and manipulative language-creates emotional distance and entrenches conflict. In contrast, NVC builds bridges by focusing on empathetic listening, honest self-expression, and the recognition of universal human needs. The principles behind NVC are not new; they echo across various religious and philosophical traditions. From the Hebrew concept of lashon hara (the prohibition of evil speech) to the Eastern principle of ahimsa (non-harm), the power of language to either heal or wound has been universally recognized. By illustrating practical, side-by-side comparisons, this paper shows how rephrasing destructive language into needs-based communication can turn confrontational interactions into collaborative problem-solving sessions. The analysis also extends to the broader societal consequences of communication, revealing how violent language contributes to political polarization, workplace toxicity, and relationship deterioration. Ultimately, this paper argues that NVC is a foundational tool for promoting healthier relationships and cultivating a more compassionate, collaborative society. Unless we adopt a communication framework that builds bridges instead of walls, society risks fracturing under the weight of its own words and tearing down the very connections it needs to survive.

title: Decoding Lease Accounting: Comparative Insights into Ind AS, IFRS, and US GAAP with Strategic Financial Implications for Corporates
affiliations: ICFAI Business School (IBS) Hyderabad, India

detail.title: Decoding Lease Accounting: Comparative Insights into Ind AS, IFRS, and US GAAP with Strategic Financial Implications for Corporates
detail.abstract: This study examines the evolution, conceptual foundations, and strategic implications of global lease accounting reforms, focusing on Ind AS 116, IFRS 16, and US GAAP ASC 842. It addresses the limitations of previous standards-IAS 17, Ind AS 17, and ASC 840which enabled operating leases to remain off balance sheet, obscuring corporate leverage and impairing comparability. The main objectives are to trace the historical development of lease accounting from 2000 to 2024, compare current frameworks in recognition, measurement, presentation, and disclosure, and evaluate their financial and strategic impact on corporates, investors, and regulators. Methodologically, the article synthesizes standard-setting documents, regulatory guidance, academic literature, industry reports, and case examples from diverse sectors such as retail, aviation, and telecommunications. It incorporates both qualitative assessment and reference to empirical evidence on ratio effects, alongside perspectives from investors, credit rating agencies, and professional accounting firms. Findings indicate that all three frameworks now require recognition of right-of-use assets and lease liabilities for most leases, improving transparency and reducing opportunities for accounting-motivated structuring. IFRS 16 and Ind AS 116 apply a single-model approach for lessees, resulting in front-loaded expense patterns and EBITDA increases, whereas ASC 842 retains a dual model, preserving straight-line expense recognition for operating leases and creating cross-framework EBITDA differences. Lessor accounting remains largely unchanged across all regimes. The capitalization of leases significantly affects leverage ratios, return metrics, and operating profit measures, with pronounced impacts in asset-intensive industries. The study concludes that while the reforms enhance decision-usefulness, reduce information asymmetry, and align accounting with economic substance, differences in income statement treatment and certain disclosure requirements under IFRS/Ind AS versus US GAAP continue to challenge global comparability.

title: Revenue Maximization Leveraging Positive Effect of Queue Length
affiliations: Department of Data and Systems Engineering, The University of Hong Kong, Department of Data and Systems Engineering, The University of Hong Kong and Department of Data and Systems Engineering, The University of Hong Kong

detail.title: Revenue Maximization Leveraging Positive Effect of Queue Length
detail.abstract: This study addresses the strategic optimization of service rates in queueing systems to attract customers by leveraging the dual nature of queue length. Contrary to the traditional view that long queues deter customers, we recognize that moderate queue lengths can act as positive signals of popularity and quality, thereby increasing customer willingness to join. To capture this complex behavioral dynamic, we develop a novel customer utility function that explicitly incorporates both the negative waiting cost and the positive "Appealing Factor" derived from queue length. Using a finite-horizon dynamic programming framework, we formulate the problem of finding the optimal time-dependent service rate policy. To estimate the key parameters of the utility function from observed data (queue lengths and joining decisions), we employ a Monte Carlo Expectation-Maximization (MCEM) algorithm, which effectively handles the unobserved heterogeneity in customer preferences. Simulation experiments validate our approach, demonstrating that the proposed dynamic policy significantly outperforms fixed-rate strategies by stably maintaining the queue at an “optimal” length. This strategy maximizes cumulative revenue by balancing the attraction of moderate queues against the risk of customer balking due to excessive wait times. The findings provide actionable managerial insights: businesses should intentionally adjust their service speed to dynamically manage queue length, transforming it from an operational burden into a powerful managerial tool.

title: Over-Investment and Firms' Green Technological Innovation
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: Over-Investment and Firms' Green Technological Innovation
detail.abstract: Green technology innovation is becoming the core driver for achieving the' dual carbon 'goals. However, over investment by companies can lead to resource misallocation, deviating from the high-quality development strategy. Based on the resource-based view and dynamic capability theory, this study selects A-share listed companies from 2007 to 2022 to empirically examine the relationship between overinvestment and corporate green technology innovation. It then introduces the moderating role of market competition intensity and external environmental uncertainty in this process, and further explores the impact of patient capital on the main effect. The results show that overinvestment inhibits corporate green technology innovation, and the increase in market competition intensity and external environmental uncertainty amplifies this inhibitory effect, which is particularly significant in companies lacking patient capital. It expands the applicability of related theories in the field of green innovation, deepening the study of the relationship between investment behavior and innovation performance.

title: Redefining Good Farming: AI-Driven Sociotechnical Change in Agriculture
affiliations: University of Milan

detail.title: Redefining Good Farming: AI-Driven Sociotechnical Change in Agriculture
detail.abstract: This chapter explores how emerging technologies available to farmers reshape the meaning of their professional practices. It argues that decision-support systems, especially those operating with high autonomy, risk diminishing farmers’ decision-making autonomy when users are excluded from their processes. Exercising moral autonomy involves defining the goods that one’s profession should pursue, such as prioritising sustainability over profitability, valuing biodiversity, or caring for individual animals. The chapter challenges the restriction of this autonomy to the relationship between a farmer and her farm, a view that is increasingly limiting in the context of AI-driven tools. Instead, it advances the perspective that these tools create opportunities to redefine the norms and practices of the sociotechnical systems into which they are integrated, embedding farmers within new networks of social relations. Particular attention is devoted to the case of farmers’ involvement in the implementation of new technologies for biodiversity monitoring, aimed at ensuring compliance with ESRS E4 standards under the CSRD.

publicationDetails.detailsText: SMU Cox School of Business Research Paper

detail.abstract: In this paper, we study whether acquisitions can improve the financial performance of firms possessing machine learning/artificial intelligence (ML/AI). First, we argue and find that this effect is significant. Then, drawing on studies proposing a weaker effect of ML/AI effectiveness when the data used are complex and contain irrelevant information, we hypothesize and find that the benefit from within-industry deals is higher than that from deals between industries. Furthermore, the effect is more significant among deals between industries when closely related. Finally, we extend these arguments to deals where both the acquirer and target have ML/AI and find the same pattern of effects. We use a number of causal inference methods on U.S. acquisition data to test our theory. Finally, we discuss the contributions of our study to research on ML/AI and acquisitions in general.

title: An Adaptive Time-Frequency Fusion Framework for Real-Time Sound Monitoring in Cvd Roller Dressing
affiliations: Hunan University, Hunan University, Hunan University, Hunan University, Hunan University and Hunan University

detail.title: An Adaptive Time-Frequency Fusion Framework for Real-Time Sound Monitoring in Cvd Roller Dressing
detail.abstract: To address the challenge of real-time monitoring in CVD roller dressing,we propose a lightweight and adaptive acoustic analysis framework. Our approach first applies a two-stage noise suppression technique combining spectral subtraction and dynamic Bayesian thresholding, designed for harsh industrial noise conditions. Then, we introduce a time-frequency fusion network that combines residual temporal convolutions and frequency-domain attention to capture transient dressing anomalies. Finally, a multi-class classifier identifies eight distinct dressing states for fine-grained anomaly detection.Experimental results on both public and real-world datasets demonstrate state-of-the-art performance with 99.12% classification accuracy and 79.63% pAUC under low false-positive rates, all while achieving real-time inference.The implementation of our framework is publicly available to facilitate reproducibility and further research at https://github.com/meihuoAI/ATFF-CVD-Dressing.

detail.title: Historical Trends in Gender and Politics: Exploring the evolution of Women's Political Representation Over Time. A Case Study of Ghana
detail.abstract: This paper explores the historical and structural factors influencing women's political representation in Ghana. Using a literature-based approach, it traces the evolution of female participation from pre-colonial to post-independence Ghana, examining how colonial legacies, patriarchy, and socio-cultural norms have shaped contemporary gender dynamics in political leadership. The paper highlights the persistent underrepresentation of women despite legal and institutional reforms and provides a critical analysis of barriers such as limited access to resources, male-dominated institutions, and internalized gender biases. It concludes with strategic policy recommendations including affirmative action, gender quotas, and women empowerment initiatives to promote inclusive governance and gender parity in decision-making.

detail.abstract: This review of reviews (Sutton et al., 2019) was guided by the research question: Does the adoption of urban climate adaptation policies (X) reduce the impact of extreme climate events (Y)? Although there are discrepancies among countries in pollutant emissions, the urban contexts of developing countries — or the Global South — are among the most affected by climate change. This is due to the high levels of vulnerability in these regions, resulting from rapid urban population growth and the lack of adequate planning in adaptation and climate resilience policies. This study compiles evidence that the implementation of technologies to support climate adaptation has a medium-to-high positive effect in mitigating extreme climate events. However, the use of such technologies entails high initial adoption costs. While policymakers generally view their implementation favorably, the population — particularly the most vulnerable — expresses reservations concerning the areas that benefit from these measures.

title: Digital Business Stategy and Entrepreneurship Sustainability in Anambra State, Nigeria

detail.abstract: This study examined the effect of digital business strategy on the entrepreneurship sustainability in Anambra State, Nigeria. The study inves gated the effect of social media business strategy on entrepreneurship sustainability; the effect of affiliate business strategy on entrepreneurship sustainability; and the effect of mobile business strategy on entrepreneurship sustainability in Anambra State Nigeria. Relevant literature were reviewed. The study was anchored on Cue U liza on Theory, The study adopted the Survey research design strategy. The survey instrument used in this study was structured ques onnaire with 5 Likert scale response. The popula on of this study comprises 2093 registered entrepreneurship business in Anambra. The sta s cal formula by Borg and Gall was employed to determine the sample size of 404. The instruments were subjected to face and content validity. The reliability of the ques onnaire was established through the test-retest and Cronbachi's Alpha. Simple percentage analysis was used in the analyzing research ques on. Hypotheses for the study were tested using Simple regression analysis. The findings of the study were summarized as follows: Social media business strategy had a significant posi ve effect on entrepreneurship sustainability (t =16.381, p<0.05). Affiliate business strategy had a significant posi ve effect on entrepreneurship sustainability (t =22.665, p<0.05), and mobile business strategy has a significant posi ve effect on entrepreneurship sustainability in Anambra State, Nigeria (t =23.361, p<0.05).The study concluded that that digital business strategy had a significant posi ve effect on entrepreneurship sustainability in Anambra State, Nigeria. The study recommended that management of entrepreneurship businesses should deploy social media business strategy services that are focused on the customer needs to ensure entrepreneurship sustainability; and they should rely on social media networks to foster corporate engagement and rollout of new products in the marke ng. The study also recommended that entrepreneurship management should collaborate with technology firms that can help in designing business tools and undertake affiliate business strategy, which can drive web traffic and ranking of the small and medium enterprises website in other to improve sales performance.

title: A Systematic Approach to Segmentation Analysis Using Machine Learning for Donation-Based Crowdfunding
affiliations: Singapore University of Social Sciences and Singapore University of Social Sciences

detail.title: A Systematic Approach to Segmentation Analysis Using Machine Learning for Donation-Based Crowdfunding
detail.abstract: Donation-based crowdfunding rose in popularity in the last five years. Yet the lack of customer provided information crowdfunding platforms challenged segmentation analysis for marketing decision-making. Our study solved a common problem that many donation-based crowdfunding platforms faced in segmentation analysis in the absence of donor descriptive attributes as well as unobserved customer heterogeneity. Using data from the world's only donation-based crowdfunding charity, we segment online donors' behavior with machine learning clustering algorithms by combining recency, frequency and monetary values (RFM) metric with donors' campaign preferences. We identify and compare the optimal number of donor clusters from different clustering algorithms. This segmentation analysis with machine learning, we termed 'RFMP' framework, offers a robust and novel approach to parsimoniously segment online behavior using observed and unobserved customer heterogeneity when extant segmentation strategies typically apply RFM metric in combination with demographic and socioeconomic attributes to infer and predict customer behavior. The resulting donor clusters inform marketing decision-making in the design and implementation of crowdfunding campaigns for charitable causes. Our project contributes to the application of machine learning in marketing strategy.

title: Factors Affecting the Loyalty of Public Bank Employees in Bangladesh

detail.title: Factors Affecting the Loyalty of Public Bank Employees in Bangladesh
detail.abstract: The Banking sector is the most stable sector compared to other industrial units of Bangladesh. Presently, there are fifty-nine scheduled banks, including nine public banks in Bangladesh. A large number of people as employees are being connected with these banks. Their loyalty towards their jobs, along with other factors has an impact on the bank's overall performance in this sector. Hence, this paper aims at evaluating the factors affecting the loyalty of public bank employees in Bangladesh. The Literature review found that various intrinsic and extrinsic factors impacts the fidelity of Public Bank employees in Bangladesh. Some innate factors like level of satisfaction, verbal performance appraisal, organizational reputation plays a major impact on the loyalty of the employees. Moreover, some extrinsic factors like compensation, training, career development, working environment impacts directly on the fealty of the employees. These factors are independent variables. Moreover, organizational well-being, financial performance are dependent variables. This study has been based on a survey of 200 employees of five leading public banks of Bangladesh.

title: Identifying and Evaluating Factors Influencing Technology Adoption: A Multi-Pilot Study within the Pharaon Project

detail.title: Identifying and Evaluating Factors Influencing Technology Adoption: A Multi-Pilot Study within the Pharaon Project
detail.abstract: IntroductionThe global increase in the older adult population has amplified interest in supporting aging in place. However, age-related physical and cognitive limitations as well as caregivers’ demand pose significant challenges. Assistive technologies can enhance autonomy, social connection and health management, but their long-term adoption and use remain limited.MethodsThis study, conducted within the Pharaon project, explores the complex factors influencing technology use among older adults, after 12 months of use, focusing on the Italian pilot and integrating insights from other European sites.ResultsInitial findings revealed several challenges, refined through cross-site collaboration. Thirty factors were identified, including personal characteristics, motivational aspects, technical design, social dynamics, and environmental context. These were rated by participating teams and 25 were retained for deeper analysis. An interconnection analysis explored how these factors influenced one another. Highly interconnected factors, such as social context, personalized training, ease of use, and cognitive changes, were central to understanding and improving technology adoption. In contrast, aspects like education level, internet access, and technical requirements appeared less interconnected, indicating more isolated effects.DiscussionThis multi-site, empirical investigation emphasizes the complex and interconnected nature of technology adoption among older adults. Our findings underscore the need for user-centered design, tailored training, and sensitivity to social context. Furthermore, the interactive mapping of interrelated factors provides a practical framework for developers and policymakers to target impactful interventions. To our knowledge, this is the first cross-pilot study to empirically define and score factors affecting older adults’ technology use based on multi-pilot data across Europe, offering valuable insights for long-term, meaningful engagement.

title: Self-Citation Versus External Citation in Academic Publishing: A Critical Analysis of Citation Reliability, Publication Biases, And Scientific Quality Assessment
affiliations: Shenyang Normal University

detail.title: Self-Citation Versus External Citation in Academic Publishing: A Critical Analysis of Citation Reliability, Publication Biases, And Scientific Quality Assessment
detail.abstract: This paper examines the complex relationship between self-citation and external citation in academic publishing, with particular attention to their reliability as indicators of scientific quality. Through analysis of recent citation patterns, publication biases, and case studies in electromagnetic wave absorption research, we demonstrate that traditional assumptions about citation value are fundamentally flawed. While external citations are conventionally viewed as more valuable than self-citations, our analysis reveals that external citations can perpetuate scientific errors when authors uncritically cite high-impact journal publications without proper evaluation. Conversely, self-citations may represent genuine scientific rigor when authors acknowledge their own correction of established errors. The paper presents evidence that high-impact journals and peer-review processes do not guarantee scientific validity, and proposes reforms to citation practices, peer review, and scientific publishing to better serve the advancement of knowledge.

title: Financial Technology (Fintech) and Tax Compliance among Informal Enterprises in Nigeria
affiliations: Independent

detail.title: Financial Technology (Fintech) and Tax Compliance among Informal Enterprises in Nigeria
detail.abstract: The informal sector constitutes a significant share of Nigeria's economy but remains largely outside the tax net, posing a persistent challenge to revenue generation. This study examines the impact of Financial Technology (FinTech) adoption on tax compliance among informal enterprises in Nigeria. Using a mixed-methods approach, data were collected from 362 informal enterprise operators through structured questionnaires and 15 key informant interviews with tax officials, FinTech providers, and sector leaders. Quantitative analysis, including Pearson correlation and multiple regression, revealed a strong positive relationship (r = 0.641, p < 0.05) between FinTech usage-particularly mobile money platforms, POS systems, and e-tax portalsand tax compliance behaviour. Perceived ease of use (β = 0.427, p < 0.05) and trust in FinTech platforms (β = 0.392, p < 0.05) emerged as significant predictors of voluntary compliance. However, adoption barriers such as low digital literacy, poor internet connectivity, limited awareness of e-tax systems, and transaction costs persist. Qualitative findings further highlight that compliance is influenced by perceptions of fairness and transparency in tax administration. The study concludes that FinTech can enhance tax compliance if complemented by taxpayer education, infrastructure expansion, cost reduction measures, and trust-building initiatives.

title: Does The Belt and Road Initiative Boost Chinese Automobile Exports? A Staggered Adoption Approach
affiliations: Oklahoma State University and Oklahoma State University

detail.title: Does The Belt and Road Initiative Boost Chinese Automobile Exports? A Staggered Adoption Approach
detail.abstract: We examine whether China's ambitious Belt and Road Initiative assisted its export performance in the final automobile sector, a market that has been challenging for the Chinese economy. We use the recent econometric technique of heterogeneity robust DID estimators for staggered timing. We also control for anticipation effects and potential BRI selection endogeneity using IVs. Using data from 2005-2019, our estimates find that China's final automobile exports to the BRI partner destination countries after these countries became signatories almost doubled relative to that of the export to non-BRI partner destinations, and the effect for net-exports is an increase of about 59%. Sub-sample analyses indicate that the positive effect is stronger for China's export to lower-income partners compared to its exports to relatively higher income destinations. The results are robust across alternate methods and specifications.

title: Impact of the Indian “De-Monetization” Policy on its Export Performance
affiliations: Oklahoma State University and Oklahoma State University - Stillwater, Spears School of Business

detail.title: Impact of the Indian “De-Monetization” Policy on its Export Performance
detail.abstract: We examine the export impact of the Indian government's surprise move to invalidate 86% of existing currencies overnight, in an attempt to eliminate illegal and untaxed transactions, and to make the financial system more reliant on electronic transactions. This policy was implemented within a production structure that significantly depended on cash and informal credit sources, and a banking infrastructure that did not reach all corners of the economy. Due to the unexpectedness of this policy, the impact is predicted to have been stronger in the short run than the long run as the economy adjusted to the new system. The Synthetic-control-method, with its ability to accommodate scenarios where the policy impact may vary across post-treatment periods, provides a suitable tool for our analysis, while the unexpectedness of the policy circumvents anticipation issues, making it an ideal candidate for SCM analysis. No long-term improvements though significant short-term losses in exports values due to this policy are uncovered that are robust across alternate specifications and estimation methods.

title: State Oil Regimes in Transition: The Political Economy of NOCs in the Age of Climate Change
affiliations: University College London

detail.title: State Oil Regimes in Transition: The Political Economy of NOCs in the Age of Climate Change
detail.abstract: National Oil Companies (NOCs) produce most of oil&gas and hold the majority of fossil fuel reserves, but are also major employers, bastions of energy security and social consent through rent creation in 67 countries. Their transformation in the age of climate change is heavily shaped by political economy conditions and constrains which can open or foreclose different transition pathways. This paper studies the political economy of NOCs in the age of climate change through a regulation approach. Five areas of political economy, identified from eleven streams of literature, inform the institutional forms of the State Oil Regime. The regulation approach of the State Oil Regime is then operationalised and tested to explain the role of Thailand’s NOC during the Bio-Circular-Green policy of the NCPO military government (2014-2019), using primary interviews and statistics. This paper contributes to the study of these energy incumbents and of developmental environmentalism, including green reformism as a legitimisation strategy across military-led, one-party states and other hybrid political systems. The paper uncovers the opportunities for sustainability transition pathways opened when hierarchically superior institutional forms—especially during periods of low oil prices in international markets—empower NOCs to advance policies that promote their transitions.

title: News Publishers, Digital Platforms, and Bargaining Codes: Debunking the Free-Riding Myth
affiliations: Università degli Studi della Basilicata

detail.title: News Publishers, Digital Platforms, and Bargaining Codes: Debunking the Free-Riding Myth

declarations.funderStatement: The study has been conducted as part of the research activities promoted by the International Center for Law & Economics (ICLE). ICLE has received financial support from numerous companies, foundations, and individuals, including firms with interests both supportive of and in opposition to the ideas expressed in this and other ICLE-supported works. ICLE support is in the form of unrestricted, general support.

detail.abstract: In response to the longstanding crisis in the publishing industry, a range of regulatory measures has been proposed and implemented worldwide, aiming to compel large online platforms to negotiate the use of news content and provide fair remuneration to publishers. From this perspective, the structural decline of the publishing sector is attributed to digital platforms capturing a significant share of advertising revenues by free-riding on publishers' investments in news production. Moreover, due to their reliance on referral traffic, publishers are perceived to suffer from a structural imbalance in bargaining power vis-à-vis these platforms. Within this framework, by introducing a revenue transfer mechanism based on a mandatory negotiation process, the Australian model has gained prominence and influenced policy approaches in several other jurisdictions. Against this background, the paper adopts a different research perspective. Rather than presuming the existence of a free-riding problem, it critically examines whether the rationale underlying these regulatory initiatives has been substantiated and supported by empirical evidence. The paper contends that the free-riding narrative serves chiefly as a rhetorical tool, strategically used to legitimize a mandated transfer of revenue that policymakers appear ready to pursue even in the absence of clear evidence that platform-based business models have caused economic harm to press publishers.

title: Destabilizing Digital Bank Walks
affiliations: Stanford University, Columbia Business School and University of Chicago - Booth School of Business

detail.title: Destabilizing Digital Bank Walks
detail.abstract: We develop a model of "stickiness" of bank deposits to study the effect of digitalization on the size and duration of the value of the deposit franchise and, ultimately, on banks' stability. The model predicts that digitalization increases the sensitivity of deposit levels and rates to changes in the Fed funds rate. We test these predictions using data on the U.S. banking sector, and find that, when interest rates rise, deposit outflows, or "walks", and deposit rate pass-through are significantly larger at banks with mobile apps and brokerage services. We use these estimates to predict the effects of digitalization on bank stability. Digitalization has ambiguous effects on the value of the deposit franchise, depending on the magnitude of the reduction in the marginal cost of servicing deposits. Still, it unambiguously increases the deposit franchise duration, undermining bank stability.

title: Probability of Default, Leverage and Dynamics
affiliations: Deutsche Bundesbank, University of Konstanz - Department of Economics and University of Groningen

detail.title: Probability of Default, Leverage and Dynamics
detail.abstract: This paper analyzes the dynamics of German firms' book leverage and probabilities of default (PD), reported quarterly by German financial institutions to Deutsche Bundesbank. The development of PDs is modelled as an AR process of PD changes and an initial PD. Regressions show mean diversion of the PDs in the short run and mean reversion to long-term target PDs over longer time intervals. The expected PD does not converge monotonically to the target PD, but overshoots and oscillates with declining amplitude. We obtain similar dynamics for book leverage. Convergence is faster when PDs start at a higher level.

title: Did Higher Individual Taxes Spur Firm Investment? The 2013 Obama Individual Investment Tax
affiliations: University of Texas at San Antonio - Department of Finance, Loyola Marymount University - College of Business Administration and Loyola Marymount University - Department of Finance

detail.title: Did Higher Individual Taxes Spur Firm Investment? The 2013 Obama Individual Investment Tax
detail.abstract: This paper examines the largest tax increase on individual investment income in U.S. history and its impact on corporate investment. Despite concerns about disrupting capital formation, firms with investors most affected by the tax increase reduce dividends and increase investment relative to less-affected peers. Research and development (R&D)-intensive firms redirect cash from dividend reductions to fund more R&D, yielding more highly cited patents, while non-R&D firms increase acquisitions. To support our main findings, we conduct a series of placebo, falsification, and robustness tests. These complementary tests provide strong support for the validity of our identification strategy and the causal interpretation of our main results. Overall, this paper contributes to the literature on taxation and corporate behavior, providing novel evidence that increases in individual-level taxes influence corporate financial policies and investment decisions.

title: על אשראי צרכני, כלכלה התנהגותית והגנה על צרכנים || The Case of Consumer Credit, Behavioral Economics and Consumer Protection

detail.title: על אשראי צרכני, כלכלה התנהגותית והגנה על צרכנים || The Case of Consumer Credit, Behavioral Economics and Consumer Protection
detail.abstract:
תקציר בעברית: במאמר זה יוצגו הסיכונים אשר אורבים לצרכנים בנטילת אשראי כפי שמזהה אותם הכלכלה ההתנהגותית; המענה החסר בדין הקיים בישראל; וההסדר הרגולטורי החדשני שמתפתח בנושא זה באנגליה בשנים האחרונות. הכלכלה ההתנהגותית מזהה ומדייקת את הבנתנו בדבר הטיות ויורסטיקות אשר משפיעות על החלטות צרכנים בנטילת אשראי, דוגמת העדפת הווה, אמונה שגוייה ביכולת פרעון עתידי ועוד. היא גם מסייעת לנו להבין מדוע "מוצר" האשראי מתאפיין בריבוי ובעוצמה גבוהה של הטיות כאמור בהשוואה למוצרים אחרים בשל, בין היתר, מורכבת המוצר בהיבטי תמחור, פריסת העלויות והתועלות לאורך זמן, וקושי של הצרכנים לפתח ידע עצמאי מתוך התנסות. לצד תובנות אלה, יוצגו במאמר גם מחקרי שטח בעולם שבהם ממצאים אמפיריים הן בדבר ההטיות מהן סובלים הצרכנים והן בדבר שימוש בפועל בהטיות הללו על-ידי ספקי האשראי הצרכני.

בפרק אשר דן בהתמודדות הדין הישראלי עם הנושא, ממופות הוראות הדין השונות ומוצג שמדובר במענה חסר ביותר. אמנם ישנם הסדרים נקודתיים, "כללים" ספציפיים, אשר ניכר כי עוצבו מתוך הבנה והתייחסות לכשלים שמזהה הכלכלה ההתנהגותית. ואולם הסדרים אלה הם נקודתיים, ולכן מעצם טיבם אינם מכסים את מלא קשת המקרים בהם יש צורך בהגנה על הצרכנים. בכל הנוגע ל"סטנדרטים" רחבים יותר בדין, דוגמת איסור ניצול מצוקה או "בורות" של הלקוח – הרי שהללו עוצבו בעיקרם כדי לתת מענה לתפיסה כלכלית ישנה יותר, ללא הפנמה של התובנות אשר עולות מהכלכלה ההתנהגותית. גם כללי "ממשל פנימי" אשר נותני האשראי השונים בישראל חייבים להנהיג, מתייחסים רק במשורה להגנה על הצרכנים (ויותר להגנה על הגוף הפיננסי) ואינם מספקים מענה.

לבסוף יוצג ההסדר הרגולטורי החדשני שהחל להנהיג הרגולטור האנגלי במהלך שנת 2023: Consumer Duty Rule. הסדר חדשני זה נועד לספק מענה מקיף ושיטתי לסוגיית ההגנה על צרכני שירותים פיננסיים ובכללם נוטלי אשראי, והוא נבנה מתוך כוונה לייתן מענה מקיף גם לכשלים אשר עולים מתובנות הכלכלה ההתנהגותית.

title: Do G-SIBs Engage in Window-dressing Behavior? An Empirical Analysis
affiliations: Deutsche Bundesbank and Deutsche Bundesbank

detail.title: Do G-SIBs Engage in Window-dressing Behavior? An Empirical Analysis
detail.abstract: This paper examines whether global systemically important banks (G-SIBs) engage in window-dressing behavior to circumvent or reduce regulatory requirements, increasing vulnerability to economic shocks. Using a comprehensive global bank sample, we uncover evidence of such practices: G-SIBs reduce year-end exposures used for G-SIB capital buffer calculations, by roughly twice the magnitude of non-G-SIBs, and reverse these cuts early the next year. This pattern is strongest among G-SIBs that are near bucket thresholds or subject to high G-SIB capital surcharges.

title: General Theory of Investment Treaty Arbitration and International Investment Law: Legal Foundations, Substantive Protections, and Practical Considerations
affiliations: System for International Law and Order L.L.C. (SiLO)

detail.title: General Theory of Investment Treaty Arbitration and International Investment Law: Legal Foundations, Substantive Protections, and Practical Considerations
detail.abstract: This paper provides an overview of investment treaty arbitration and international investment law, highlighting the legal basis for ISDS and the exceptional standing of private investors under IIAs. It examines key substantive protections-non-discrimination, fair and equitable treatment, full protection and security, expropriation, and umbrella clauses, along side recognized exceptions, defenses, and practical issues such as proof, damages, enforcement, and choice of arbitration rules. By situating ISDS jurisprudence within the broader evolution of global economic governance, the paper illuminates the ongoing tension between investor protection and host state sovereignty. It offers a concise framework for understanding current principles and anticipating future developments in international investment law.

title: Structural Equity Option Pricing: Implications for Credit Risk
affiliations: Johns Hopkins University - Carey Business School and International Monetary Fund (IMF)

detail.title: Structural Equity Option Pricing: Implications for Credit Risk
detail.abstract: We develop a structural model for equity option pricing that incorporates stochastic volatility and time-varying asset jumps. The asset dynamics belong to the broad class of affine models, but the corresponding equity dynamics are non-affine, making traditional Fourier-based valuation methods computationally intensive. We address this challenge by training a deep neural network to approximate the option pricing function. Using liquid, exchange-traded equity options, we estimate key firm-level characteristics, specifically, asset variance and market leverage, which are used to derive an option-implied probability of default (PD). This PD co-moves with over-the-counter CDS spreads but also exhibits persistent residuals that we link to intermediary constraints. Our approach delivers a real-time, forward-looking, equity market-based measure of credit risk that is, by construction, unaffected by the illiquidity and frictions inherent in credit markets.

title: Commuting Time, Flexibility, and Job Security
affiliations: University of Sheffield, University of Bonn and affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: Commuting Time, Flexibility, and Job Security
detail.abstract: We analyse workers’ preferences for wages, commute time, working-from-home, flexibility, job security, and social impact using discrete choice experiments from 2022 and 2025 with about 4,000 Flemish employees. Preferences for shorter commutes and flexible schedules remain stable post-pandemic, with substantial willingness-to-pay (WTP) for these attributes. However, WTP for job security declined and the value of socially impactful jobs disappeared by 2025. Latent class analysis identifies distinct groups differing in their valuation of non-wage attributes, linked to education and commuting experiences. Our results highlight the persistent demand for flexibility and commute benefits along with the shifting views on security and the meaning of jobs.

title: The Gains from International Carbon Trade and the Ranking of Suboptimal Climate Policies
affiliations: University of California, Berkeley

detail.title: The Gains from International Carbon Trade and the Ranking of Suboptimal Climate Policies
detail.abstract: International negotiations have neither created a foundation for a global carbon market nor set emissions reduction targets to respect a 2 o C ceiling on temperature increase. A novel method of estimating gains from the international reallocation of abatement distinguishes between gains that can in principle be achieved by fiat, using public information, and those gains that require a market to reveal private or nonverifiable information. The second type of gain is much larger than the fiat gains; it equals 7% of aggregate abatement costs at a policy that seeks to achieve a 40% emissions reduction. However, these gains would be enough to finance only a small increase in abatement. The suboptimality of abatement targets favors quotas over taxes, but that small advantage is swamped by the cost of a missing carbon market.

title: Organizational Transmission of AI: Managerial Influence on Generative AI Adoption
affiliations: Stanford University

detail.title: Organizational Transmission of AI: Managerial Influence on Generative AI Adoption
detail.abstract: Using longitudinal data from the Gallup Panel with roughly 10,000 U.S. respondents, surveyed annually between 2023 and 2025, we document new patterns in the heterogeneous adoption of generative AI and its "organizational transmission" within firms. We show that trust in leadership and clear managerial communication are the strongest predictors of employee uptake, even after accounting for income, occupation, and sector. Exploiting within-person variation and managerial exposure, we demonstrate that the complementarity between AI adoption and workplace culture significantly shapes employee outcomes. Specifically, employees who adopt AI in environments characterized by high managerial trust and clear communication exhibit markedly higher engagement relative to peers adopting AI under weaker managerial conditions. These results highlight the central role of managers in mediating technology diffusion and underscore that the productivity gains from AI hinge not only on the technology itself, but also on the organizational context in which it is deployed.

title: Reviving Shareholder Voice by Redefining Pre-Suit Demand

detail.title: Reviving Shareholder Voice by Redefining Pre-Suit Demand

publicationDetails.detailsText: Fordham Journal of Corporate and Financial Law, Volume XXXI

detail.abstract: This article diagnoses, and seeks to cure, an undertheorized dynamic relationship between two levers of shareholder influence in the modern public corporation: suit and voice. This article demonstrates that, under current Delaware law, a shareholder must stifle its voice in order to retain the ability to pursue a viable derivative claim, thus inhibiting the shareholder's monitoring and information-sharing roles. In particular, the onerous "demand made" litigation pathway disincentives pre-suit demand, and the expansive definition of presuit demand captures shareholder communications to the board seeking corrective action other than litigation. To avoid this collision between suit and voice, this article proposes a narrowed definition of pre-suit demand, which furthers the policy rationales underlying the pre-suit demand requirement without stifling shareholder voice.

title: Effect of Climate Change on the Korean Economy: Aggregated VAR with Functional Data
affiliations: Sungkyunkwan University and Bank of Korea - Economic Research Institute

detail.title: Effect of Climate Change on the Korean Economy: Aggregated VAR with Functional Data

publicationDetails.journalName: Bank of Korea Economic Research Institute Research Paper Series

detail.abstract: This study investigates the economic effects of climate change on small open economies within a broader global context, using South Korea as a case study. We apply advanced econometric techniques to analyze high-dimensional functional data and employ an Instrumental Factor Model to construct a Global Climate Index that captures global climate dynamics. Additionally, we develop localized seasonal weather indices for South Korea. An aggregated VAR framework is employed to es- timate the dynamic effects of the constructed climate index on key macroeconomic variables in South Korea. Global temperature and economic shocks are identified to reveal how global temperature changes affect countries with different income levels and how these effects propagate to South Korea’s economy. Our findings indicate that global temperature shocks have significantly negative and persistent effects on GDP worldwide. In contrast, local weather variations in South Korea, though volatile, exert minimal direct influence on domestic GDP and CPI. The pa- per contributes to climate-economy research by offering a scalable methodological framework capable of handling large datasets and complex interactions. It provides important insights for policymakers, emphasizing the need for international cooper- ation and sustainable strategies to mitigate the economic risks of climate change.

title: Antitrust's North Star: The Continued and Nameless Judicial Deference Toward the Merger Guidelines
affiliations: Stanford University

detail.title: Antitrust's North Star: The Continued and Nameless Judicial Deference Toward the Merger Guidelines
detail.abstract:
In December 2023, the Department of Justice and the Federal Trade Commission issued the eighth iteration of the Merger Guidelines-guidance documents that outline the antitrust agencies' priorities when reviewing a merger or acquisition. These documents are not legally binding. And yet over the past fifty years, courts have heavily relied upon the Guidelines to decide antitrust cases, citing them in equal breath with statutes and case law. This is a deference that has unfolded quietly. Courts piling on citations to the Guidelines have not articulated exactly what kind of deference these guidance documents are receiving. Nor have they explained why this deference is happening at all. 

This Note seeks to shine a light on how and why the Merger Guidelines climbed to such an incredibly prominent position in modern antitrust jurisprudence. First, it charts the history of the Guidelines' birth and development from 1968 to 2023, highlighting how the Guidelines and the case law gradually came into conversation with one another. It then explores how the antitrust agencies came to voluntarily adopt notice-and-comment procedures that mimic the Administrative Procedure Act's requirements, despite having no obligation to do so. This Note argues that the agencies have sought to cloak the Guidelines in greater procedure in order to bolster their popular legitimacy and temper judicial skepticism. After categorizing the specific language judges have used to refer to the Guidelines in merger decisions from December 2000 to February 2025, this Note concludes that courts have generally failed to label their deference. From this silence, the Note predicts courts will continue to rely on the Guidelines and argues they should apply Skidmore deference when doing so. This Note closes with an exploration of whether the Supreme Court's doctrinal tidal waves in in deference and finality might uproot the thus far nameless deference. The first year of cases issued under the 2023 Guidelines reveals that the Guidelines have largely remained persuasive to the courts. Antitrust's north star continues to light the way.

title: A Promise in the Name of God
affiliations: Tulane University - A.B. Freeman School of Business and Tulane University - A.B. Freeman School of Business

detail.title: A Promise in the Name of God
detail.abstract: In countries with weak institutions, sellers face challenges in assuring buyers of product quality. Using hundreds of audio-recorded trade negotiations in Afghanistan, we document that sellers often invoke God to address this problem. Such verbal commitments are more prevalent when product quality is difficult to verify ex ante and when sellers lack a fixed location, limiting the role of reputation as a commitment device. We posit that these commitments operate as a signaling device, as making false claims under divine invocation is believed to entail cosmic costs. Findings from two field experiments corroborate this interpretation: goods sold under such invocations are of higher quality, and such invocations significantly increase sales. These effects are stronger when the mechanism is more salient, for example, when sellers exhibit outward signs of religiosity. Our findings indicate that verbal commitments can serve as credible signals, challenging the prevailing view that they are merely cheap talk.

title: The Nature of the Firm and Endogenous Production Networks
affiliations: Shanghai Jiao Tong University (SJTU)

detail.title: The Nature of the Firm and Endogenous Production Networks
detail.abstract: This paper develops a tractable general equilibrium model where production networks are formed endogenously. Drawing on transaction cost theory, the analysis centers on firms' "make-or-buy" decisions, which are driven by an asymmetric tax wedge between market and internal sourcing. This core mechanism shapes both firm boundaries and the aggregate network structure. Within this framework, the paper establishes the existence and uniqueness of the equilibrium and yields three key findings. First, firm-level productivity gains can paradoxically lower aggregate output through inefficient integration. Second, the tax wedge can distort the identity of specialist producers. Third, uniform, fully-rebated taxes are shown to be non-neutral when they alter firms' organizational boundaries. More broadly, the paper provides a framework that bridges the theory of the firm with macroeconomics, demonstrating the fundamental role of institutional frictions in shaping aggregate outcomes.

title: Counterfiets the Devil Killing Originality in SMES of Uganda A Case of Kacita, Kampala
affiliations: Independent

detail.title: Counterfiets the Devil Killing Originality in SMES of Uganda A Case of Kacita, Kampala

declarations.ethicsApproval: A written consent was written to the leader of Kampala city traders association so as to collect data.
declarations.funderStatement: This study was self funded with no support from any organization.

detail.abstract: Counterfeit products are unauthorized replicas of genuine goods, typically produced to deceive consumers by imitating the original brand's trademark, packaging, or design, and infringing intellectual property rights (OECD/EUIPO, 2019). Counterfeit commodities or imitated goods represent an extensive and established industry that is global and has affected almost all countries in a distributive measure. Counterfeit goods vary from illegible production of copyrighted goods to breaches of commodity patents in the case of capital and technical products, as well as industrial goods. This study focused on finding out whether trading in counterfeit goods erodes trade-in genuine goods. The key intentions of the study were; to find out whether trade in counterfeit goods (General Merchandise and Shoes) erodes genuine goods from the market; to identify the drivers of counterfeit trade in Uganda and to use findings of the study to inform policy decision making. This research used a descriptive cross-sectional research design which employed both quantitative as well as qualitative approaches. Data for this study was collected from traders under their umbrella body called Kampala City Traders Association (KACITA), operating within Kampala Capital City Authority (KCCA) using structured open-ended questionnaires and interviews. Findings from the study indicated that counterfeit goods have the capacity and in the case of Uganda have eroded genuine goods from the market. Traders confessed that, because of the consumer changes in preferences and availability of cheap goods, it becomes illogical to sell genuine goods that are relatively scarce, highly expensive and with a low velocity in terms of the period they spend on shelves. This means traders had one option shifting to imitated goods that have a ready market. Similarly, it was found out that the biggest driver for counterfeit business was the expected profits from the business but also the weak regulatory framework and enforcement of the anti-counterfeiting Act. The study recommends that a deeper analysis of the legal framework for the anti-counterfeiting regime for Uganda be revisited and strengthened. Government of Uganda should set up an enforcement mechanism or a branch in police with specialized roles of fighting the counterfeit vice as well ensuring compliance. Additionally, the study recommends the government provide relief incentives in the form of tax reduction among others. This will help lower the price burden and make competition with other goods more achievable as both fake and genuine goods will have a close pricing strategy making goods similarly cheaper.
