detail.abstract:
This paper applies the Economic Relativity Model (ERM) to a comparative study of the structural
economic dynamics of the United States, Japan, the European Union, and Russia. By analyzing the
trajectory of each country’s cost-to-price ratio (c/p), theoretical capacity (F), and systemic friction (a),
we identify divergence in economic incentives and predict potential strategic inflection points. The
analysis is grounded in the ERM master function:

This function models economic output (Y) as constrained by structural cost-pressure and systemic
inefficiencies, revealing the latent energy and directional momentum of economic systems. We argue
that the c/p trajectory—representing the psychological and structural pressure on decision-makers—is a
leading indicator of future economic tipping points.

title: Tariff Wars: Impact on India and World Economy.
affiliations: Institute of Chartered Accountants of India (ICAI)

detail.title: Tariff Wars: Impact on India and World Economy.
detail.abstract: This paper discusses on the global tariff wars imposed by US President Donald Trump in his second tenure in 2025. It explores the origins, progression, and implications of these trade conflicts, particularly the U.S.-China trade war and also some snapshots are provided with other countries like Mexico, Canada and European Union. The research highlights India's position by evaluating the economic and geopolitical impact, and provides a SWOT analysis in the Indian context. Furthermore, it also emphasizes the role of Chartered Accountants (CAs) and concludes with some favorable recommendations.

title: Time for Development
affiliations: International Institute for Applied Systems Analysis (IIASA) and Yale School of the Environment

detail.title: Time for Development
detail.abstract: How efficiently do societies convert collective time into the fulfillment of basic needs-and what are the implications for wellbeing and development? Traditional poverty and wellbeing metrics, such as the International Poverty Line and Multidimensional Poverty Index, largely ignore time as a critical resource. This article addresses this gap and proposes the "time conversion factor," a metric that quantifies how effectively countries transform societal time inputs into outputs that satisfy essential needs. Empirical data from time-use surveys reveal stark crosscountry differences in time spent on food provisioning, highlighting structural inequalities that limit discretionary time and economic growth. We demonstrate that time-inefficient provisioning systems trap societies in a cycle of deprivation and delayed development. Prioritizing the measurement and improvement of time conversion in provisioning systems is therefore essential to advancing sustainable wellbeing and breaking persistent cycles of inequality.

title: A Europe Fit for the Age of Startups: Rhetoric and Reality in the EU's Digital Package
affiliations: IE University - IE Law School and International Center for Law & Economics (ICLE)

detail.title: A Europe Fit for the Age of Startups: Rhetoric and Reality in the EU's Digital Package

declarations.funderStatement: This paper was written with support from the International Center for Law & Economics.

detail.abstract:
This paper examines the alignment between the European Union's ambitious goal of fostering a vibrant startup ecosystem and its recent wave of digital regulations. The analysis is framed against the backdrop of the Draghi Report’s sobering assessment of European competitiveness, which points to a widening productivity and innovation gap with global leaders. The report identifies overregulation, fragmented capital markets, and low startup activity as key contributing factors to Europe's economic challenges.

This paper argues that a fundamental tension exists between the EU's twin policy pillars of expansive digital regulation—including the Digital Markets Act (DMA), Digital Services Act (DSA), and AI Act—and its commitment to promoting startups. While policymakers often cite these regulations as crucial for creating a more level playing field, they may be working at cross purposes.

Through a review of the Digital Package's design and its accompanying impact assessments, the paper reveals a mixed and often insufficient consideration of startup-specific concerns. It finds that the impact assessments of key legislation frequently overlook the potential negative effects on nascent companies, despite empirical research showing that digital regulations have contributed to increased market concentration and a decline in startup investment.

While some acts, such as the AI Act, include specific provisions and carve-outs to ease the regulatory burden on small firms, these measures may not be sufficient to counteract broader compliance costs and bureaucratic hurdles. The cumulative weight of such obligations risks creating barriers to entry, discouraging entrepreneurship, and hampering the ability of innovative firms to scale.

The paper concludes that this misalignment between rhetoric and reality risks pushing Europe further from the technological frontier and undermining its ambition to be “fit for the Digital Age.” Without a more coherent approach that reconciles regulatory ambitions with the needs of startups, the EU may find its competitiveness and innovative capacity further diminished.

title: Pandangan Sosiologi Sastra Terhadap Estetika Marxis (A Sociology of Literature Perspective on Marxist Aesthetics)
affiliations: UIN Syarif Hidayatullah Jakarta

detail.title: Pandangan Sosiologi Sastra Terhadap Estetika Marxis (A Sociology of Literature Perspective on Marxist Aesthetics)
detail.abstract:
Indonesian Abstract: Sosiologi sastra sebagai pendekatan sastra yang mempertimbangkan manusia dan segi-segi kemasyarakatan banyak didasari oleh pandangan estetika Marxis, sebuah pandangan yang melihat hubungan sastra dan masyarakat melalui teori determinisme. Sastra dipandang sebagai cermin dari kondisi ekonomi dan proses produksi. Pandangan 'sastra sebagai cermin masyarakat' ini telah menerima banyak kritik, salah satunya dari Wellek dan Wallen (1956) yang menilai penganut estetika Marxis menetapkan kriteria non-sastra terhadap karya sastra. Namun tulisan ini berargumen bahwa kritik tersebut salah sasaran, sebab Marx dan Engels tidak pernah merumuskan estetika Marxis secara langsung dan sebetulnya pandangan estetika Marxis sejalan dengan syarat sosiologi sastra dari Alan Swingewood. Sebaliknya, kritik-kritik tersebut lebih tepat ditujukan pada perkembangan lanjutan estetika Marxis, seperti Realisme Sosialis yang digunakan sebagai alat politik oleh Vladimir Lenin dan Joseph Stalin, atau Realisme Kritis dari George Lukacs. Oleh karena itu, penting untuk membedakan antara Estetika Marxis sebagai dasar pandangan dengan Realisme Sosialis dan Realisme Kritis sebagai perkembangannya guna menghindari kekeliruan dalam analisis dan kritik.

English Abstract: Sociology of literature as an approach to literature that considers humans and social aspects is largely based on the views of Marxist aesthetics, a perspective that sees the relationship between literature and society through the theory of determinism. Literature is seen as a mirror of economic conditions and production processes. This view of 'literature as a mirror of society' has received much criticism, one of which came from Wellek and Wallen (1956) who argued that followers of Marxist aesthetics applied non-literary criteria to literary works. However, this paper argues that such criticism is misguided, as Marx and Engels never directly formulated Marxist aesthetics, and in fact, the view of Marxist aesthetics is in line with the requirements of the sociology of literature from Alan Swingewood. Conversely, these criticisms are more appropriately directed at the further development of Marxist aesthetics, such as Socialist Realism which was used as a political tool by Vladimir Lenin and Joseph Stalin, or Critical Realism from George Lukacs. Therefore, it is important to distinguish between Marxist Aesthetics as a foundational view and Socialist Realism and Critical Realism as its developments to avoid errors in analysis and criticism.

title: The Scope of Tax Accounting Research
affiliations: Duke University - Accounting, University of North Carolina (UNC) at Chapel Hill - Accounting Area and University of North Carolina at Chapel Hill

detail.title: The Scope of Tax Accounting Research
detail.abstract: We argue that tax researchers in accounting should expand the scope of their inquiry to include all types of taxes paid by all types of taxpayers, and that editors and reviewers should be more willing to review and consider such papers. Accountants in practice engage with a wide variety of taxes-such as payroll, sales, property, carbon, and other excise taxes-yet tax accounting scholars and journals have largely ignored these areas. We propose that broadening the scope of tax research will better align academic inquiry with real-world practice and public policy. Furthermore, we contend that accounting scholars bring valuable skills to the table for studying the effects of these taxes, given their institutional knowledge, familiarity with tax and accounting data, and experience with taxpayer behavior. By encouraging research on a broader set of taxes, accounting journals and tax accounting scholars have the potential to expand their impact and relevance.

title: Why Avoiding Deindustrialization Via Subsidies May Trigger a Subsidy Trap and Slow Down Green Investments
affiliations: University of Münster, WHU - Otto Beisheim School of Management and University of Düsseldorf - Düsseldorf Institute for Competition Economics (DICE)

detail.title: Why Avoiding Deindustrialization Via Subsidies May Trigger a Subsidy Trap and Slow Down Green Investments
detail.abstract: To counter the threat of deindustrialization due to soaring energy prices and facilitate a green transition, policymakers have devised new subsidy schemes such as the "bridge electricity price" (BEP). To analyze this, we develop a model, where the principal introduces a subsidy program to prevent the agent from exiting and facilitate green investments, which would end the agent's reliance on the subsidy. We demonstrate that, while successfully mitigating deindustrialization, the subsidy can lead to unintended consequences. First, the principal's commitment problem can lower investment incentives and lead to the subsidy program being everlasting. Second, it can induce a "subsidy trap", drawing non-targeted agents into the subsidy scheme. Lastly, it can reinforce the exit problem it intended to solve by encouraging opportunistic investments. When applying our results to the BEP, we conclude that the fiscal costs of this subsidy could, therefore, far exceed initial projections.

title: Simulating Electoral System Changes and How Voters Might Respond
affiliations: Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT) - Department of Political Science

detail.title: Simulating Electoral System Changes and How Voters Might Respond
detail.abstract: A crucial determinant of electoral system choice is how many seats a specific political party would win under some alternative electoral system, but this quantity has long been estimated using a simple approach that is known to have multiple major flaws. I address these problems by developing a computational formal model that estimates how the seat totals in a particular Single-Member District Plurality election might have been different if the election had been held under another electoral system, explicitly simulating how strategic voters might have voted differently. The model is falsifiable, and outperforms the widespread simple approach in estimating seat counts after New Zealand's electoral system change. I apply the model to Canada and Britain, simulating elections under Borda count and Mixed-Member Proportional systems. The results suggest that parties do not consistently support the systems that would win them the most seats.

title: Digital Operational Resilience Act (DORA) And Similar Global ICT Risk Management Frameworks Requires a Structured Approach That Balances Theory, Empirical Evidence, And Critical Analysis

detail.title: Digital Operational Resilience Act (DORA) And Similar Global ICT Risk Management Frameworks Requires a Structured Approach That Balances Theory, Empirical Evidence, And Critical Analysis

declarations.ethicsApproval: Ethics Approval This study did not involve human participants, animals, or personal identifiable data; therefore, ethics approval was not required. All secondary data used were obtained from publicly available and credible sources, including official bank reports, World Bank databases, IMF statistics, and other recognized financial data repositories.

detail.abstract: The increasing reliance on digital infrastructures in the financial sector has heightened vulnerability to cyber threats, prompting regulators to strengthen operational resilience requirements. This study investigates the impact of ICT sectoral exposure on the incidence of cyber incidents in the European Union, with a specific focus on the Digital Operational Resilience Act (DORA) framework and its global comparators. Using panel data from ENISA incident reports (2023–2024) covering EU and neighboring countries, we analyze the relationship between the proportion of incidents affecting banking, public finance, and individual sectors. Ordinary Least Squares regression reveals that banking sector exposure (% of incidents) is a statistically significant predictor of total incident counts (p < 0.001), whereas public finance and individual exposure proportions are not significant drivers. Multicollinearity diagnostics (VIF < 2.3), heteroskedasticity tests (p > 0.26), and serial correlation tests (p > 0.09) confirm the robustness of the model. The findings highlight the critical role of targeted resilience measures in the banking sector, suggesting that DORA’s emphasis on ICT risk testing, incident classification, and third-party oversight aligns with empirical risk concentrations. Comparative discussion with frameworks such as the US FFIEC CAT and APAC MAS TRM shows that while global regimes share similar principles, DORA’s legally binding scope and harmonized EU-wide enforcement mechanisms provide a more comprehensive governance structure. The study contributes to the literature by offering empirical evidence to guide policymakers, regulators, and financial institutions in prioritizing ICT risk management strategies, particularly in sectors with disproportionate exposure to cyber threats

title: AI - A Game Changer for Digitally Native Brands
affiliations: MGIMO (Moscow State University of International Relations)

detail.title: AI - A Game Changer for Digitally Native Brands
detail.abstract: This paper explores the nature, competitive advantages, and operational models of Digitally Native Brands (DNBs), with a particular focus on their integration of artificial intelligence (AI). DNBs are defined as companies born and operating primarily or exclusively online, targeting digitally native consumers through personalized and data-driven strategies. Their success is largely attributed to their deep understanding of customers, real-time analytics, and ability to leverage AI across all business functions. Unlike traditional companies, DNBs embed AI into their core from inception, using it not only for automation and efficiency but also to complement human creativity and decision-making. The paper also outlines key reasons why DNBs are more successful in AI adoption, including effective AI talent management, structured experimentation culture, and robust digital platforms.

title: The Dynamics of Technology Transfer: Multinational Investment in China and Rising Global Competition
affiliations: Federal Reserve Board of Governors, International Monetary Fund (IMF) and International Monetary Fund (IMF)

detail.title: The Dynamics of Technology Transfer: Multinational Investment in China and Rising Global Competition
detail.abstract: US multinationals form joint ventures in China for market access and lower labor costs. However, these ventures transfer knowledge to Chinese partners and local firms, increasing future competition from China. While multinationals take into account these spillovers, they don’t account for the impact on other US firms, potentially leading to over-investment from a US social perspective. We establish three novel empirical facts on spillovers and competition effects. First, Chinese parent firms of joint ventures become larger, export more, and grow technologically similar to their US partners. Second, in industries with more joint ventures, even non-participating Chinese firms grow larger and more technologically advanced. Third, US firms in these industries experience negative impacts on their size, exports, and innovation. We then develop a two-country growth model with oligopolistic competition and endogenous innovation and joint venture decisions. For the US, joint ventures generate short-run gains that are outweighed by long-run losses due to rising competition from China. Large US firms’ profits are higher with joint ventures, at the expense of small firms’ profits and the real wage. Banning joint ventures from the beginning would have raised US welfare by 1.2 percent but reduced China’s by 10.6 percent, as Chinese firms’ productivity growth is substantially delayed.

title: The Bhopal Gas Tragedy: A Case Study in Industrial Disaster and Corporate Accountability
affiliations: Kurukshetra University

detail.title: The Bhopal Gas Tragedy: A Case Study in Industrial Disaster and Corporate Accountability
detail.abstract: Purpose-To explore the actual condition of the city after the gas emission and the effects of the tragedy on the community nearby industry. Examine the roles and responsibilities of Union Carbide Corporation, its parent company and the Indian government in the disaster, highlighting failures in industrial safety, crisis management and post-tragedy justice. Evaluate the sufficiency and inadequacy of the financial compensation, legal judgement and rehabilitation given to the victims in terms of why monetary settlements alone could not heal the irreparable damage. Design/methodology/approach-The research methodology for this study involves the use of secondary data from a broad spectrum of credible references, including academic journals, books, government websites and official reports. Data collection for this research will involve reviewing the literature and relevant archive records pertaining to the subject matter of the research study. This secondary data then is analysed systematically, categorized and synthesized to satisfy the objectives of the research. It then adopts a methodology that guarantees sound foundations for the study using established information to derive significant insights and conclusions without making primary data collection. Findings-The findings of this paper reveal the devastating and long-lasting impact of the Bhopal Gas Tragedy on both the environment and the affected communities. The gas leak caused immediate death, widespread illness and long-term health issues such as respiratory diseases and birth defects. Union Carbide's negligence, along with its parent company's lack of oversight and the Indian government's failure to enforce safety regulations, played significant roles in the disaster. In addition, the financial compensation and rehabilitation efforts were found to be insufficient, leaving victims with unresolved health, psychological and social challenges, highlighting the inadequacy of monetary settlements in addressing the full extent of the tragedy. Originality/value-This paper offers an original analysis of the Bhopal Gas Tragedy by examining its longterm impact on the environment and community, highlighting corporate and government accountability and evaluating the sufficiency of compensation and rehabilitation efforts. It provides fresh insights into the inadequacies of post-tragedy responses and their lasting effects on victims.

title: The Role of Public-Private Partnerships in Capital Mobilization for Sustainable Development in African Economies
affiliations: Regional Advisory Commision on Financial Markets

detail.title: The Role of Public-Private Partnerships in Capital Mobilization for Sustainable Development in African Economies
detail.abstract: Public-private partnerships (PPPs) serve as a mechanism whereby the public and private sectors jointly mobilise funds to finance and implement development projects of mutual interest. The widespread use of PPPs in developed and emerging economies, across both social and economic sectors, attests to their perceived value. Proponents of PPPs argue that they can reduce the burden on public budgets and aid in debt management; enable projects otherwise unaffordable through traditional approaches; enhance cost-effectiveness and value for money; promote efficiency and equity; encourage innovation and technology transfer; incentivize private sector involvement; foster competition; leverage private sector expertise; attract foreign investment; generate employment; and facilitate poverty reduction and sustainable development (Mfunwa et al., 2016). Consequently, PPPs may constitute a timely and sustainable mechanism for capital mobilisation in a manner that fosters sustainable development within the African socioeconomic and political context.

title: A Civil Rights Defense Of Gentrification

detail.title: A Civil Rights Defense Of Gentrification

detail.abstract: Scholars across disciplines such as sociology, economics, and urban planning are writing about gentrification. The literature and beliefs surrounding gentrification are very diverse, but what often connects the various views is a negative perception that gentrification always disadvantages and displaces low-income minority residents, physically or culturally. But the connotations of race and class associated with gentrification in the minds of many do not align with the empirical research and scholarly findings. Thus far in law, there is no thick legal account of gentrification and its legal or policy implications. Much of the legal writing is predicated upon an inaccurate conception of what gentrification is, as opposed to exploring the assumptions upon which the conception is based. This Article argues that gentrification of low-income, segregated neighborhoods holds an untapped integrative potential. This potential remains untapped because of an undue coupling of the concepts of gentrification and displacement. According to this coupling, gentrification cannot exist without, nor can it be disassociated from, displacement of low-income and minority people. To the contrary, gentrification, in tandem with other affordable housing mechanisms, holds untapped potential to make real inroads into dismantling our segregated housing patterns. This Article offers a different approach to understanding and contextualizing gentrification. Its central contributions are twofold. It examines the widespread beliefs that form modern misperceptions about gentrification. This Article also explains how legal interventions at all levels of government can help facilitate the Fair Housing Act's (FHA) goals of equal access and integration in housing. Once examined, the core *24 issues emanating contemporary and historic animosity towards gentrification reveal themselves. Once this occurs, it becomes evident that gentrification can be part of an approach to redressing socioeconomic segregation.

title: Dark Patterns and Consumer Protection Law for App Makers
affiliations: University of Nebraska at Lincoln - College of Law

detail.title: Dark Patterns and Consumer Protection Law for App Makers
detail.abstract: Dark patterns in online commerce, especially deceptive user interface designs for apps and websites, undermine consumer autonomy and distort online markets. Although sometimes deception is intentional, the complex app development process can also unintentionally produce manipulative user interfaces. This paper discusses common design pitfalls and proposes strategies for app makers to avoid infringing user autonomy or incurring legal liability under emerging principles of consumer protection law. By focusing on choice architecture and transparent design principles, developers can both facilitate compliance and build user trust and loyalty.

title: Winners and Losers in the 2025 EU–US Trade War: Strategic Leverage or Economic Capitulation?
affiliations: University of Warsaw

detail.title: Winners and Losers in the 2025 EU–US Trade War: Strategic Leverage or Economic Capitulation?
detail.abstract: This paper examines the 2025 EU-US trade agreement as a turning point in global trade governance, highlighting its uneven consequences and the erosion of multilateral norms. While the deal averted a full-scale trade war, it entrenched asymmetries that favor US strategic sectors and select EU member states, while disadvantaging core EU industries and undermining the bloc's strategic autonomy. The agreement's structure-marked by non-reciprocal tariff ceilings and informal legal frameworks-reflects a broader shift toward bilateralism and economic coercion. Drawing on the Mavroidis & Sapir (2024) briefing and original analysis, the paper explores how the EU's internal divisions, geopolitical pressures, and reliance on defensive trade instruments have weakened its position in global negotiations. It concludes with a call for renewed commitment to transparent, rules-based trade governance, emphasizing the need to reform the WTO, restore legal clarity, and rebalance internal EU interests to ensure long-term resilience and fairness in international trade.

title: The Impact of LLM Adoption on Online User Behavior
affiliations: London Business School - Department of Marketing, UCLA Anderson, London Business School and University of California, Los Angeles (UCLA) - Anderson School of Management

detail.title: The Impact of LLM Adoption on Online User Behavior
detail.abstract: The adoption of AI tools, and especially Large Language Models (LLMs), has the potential to significantly transform how users engage with information online, potentially serving as substitutes or complements to existing digital resources. We use detailed clickstream data from 2022 and 2023 to examine users' online behavior following the adoption of large language models. We document a significant decrease in online search activity, a typical entry point to content consumption. Online searches drop slowly, suggesting a period during which users learn to use LLMs, but eventually the level of online search is more than 20% below the pre-adoption period, though there is heterogeneity across types of queries. We then turn to the effect of LLM adoption on website traffic. We document that while frequently visited websites are not affected, smaller websites suffer a significant drop in visits. In line with these results, we then report a significant drop in display ad exposures, especially to consumers with high levels of retail activity, though we do not find a reduction in search ad exposures. Last, we study two distinct categories of websites: education-related websites and user-generated content platforms. We document a significant drop in visits to education-related websites and heterogeneity across user-generated content platforms with a pronounced negative effect on Stack Overflow but no significant effect on Wikipedia, Reddit and social media. We discuss implications for online content creators, for GenAI firms and for public policy.

title: The Truth Behind the EV Stall: A Process-Mining Autopsy of Systemic Failure and the Limits of the ISO Framework

detail.abstract: The global electric-vehicle (EV) market-once on a trajectory of exponential growth-is now experiencing a marked slowdown, often described as a "stall." While many analyses single out factors such as macroeconomic headwinds or policy shifts, this paper argues that the root cause is a deeper systemic failure across the EV ecosystem. We adopt an analytical lens that treats the ISO framework as a management blueprint, the Integrated Management System (IMS) as an enterprise operating system, and process mining as a diagnostic "X-ray." Using a conceptual process-mining analysis spanning consumers, manufacturers, and policymakers, we identify critical bottlenecks and process disconnects. These bottlenecks are then mapped to-and stratified intofour fundamental limits: biological, sociological, economic, and technological. The analysis suggests that current market stagnation is not a failure of EV technology per se, but a consequence of the ecosystem simultaneously hitting these four limits. We further contend that projects were advanced prematurely, propelled by technological optimism and industrial-policy imperatives that discounted foreseeable risks. In Europe in particular, a rapid pivot toward EVs-partly to counter Japanese automakers' leadership in hybrid vehicles (HV)-often sidelined the perspective of end users, the most critical stakeholders. This reflects a serious flaw in the governing management philosophy of Total Management (TM). On this basis, we demonstrate why conventional ISO frameworks are inherently illequipped to manage-or resolve-such system-level constraints.

title: False Confidence in Systematic Trading: The Illusion of Speed
affiliations: Université Paris VI Pierre et Marie Curie

detail.title: False Confidence in Systematic Trading: The Illusion of Speed
detail.abstract: In systematic trading, speed sells, but much of it is an illusion. Short lookback windows, long favoured for their lightning-fast adaptation to market shifts, are often less a source of genuine edge than a statistical mirage. Their apparent precision is built on small samples, unstable estimates, and performance metrics riddled with the same noise they claim to exploit. Traders embrace them for their immediacy, their bias toward 'fresh' data, and their low latency in execution, yet these same qualities amplify randomness and reduce reliability. By examining both the statistical underpinnings and the practical incentives that sustain their use, this article shows how the promise of fast signals can dissolve under scrutiny, revealing that in many cases, speed simply means being wrong sooner.

title: Econometrics vs. Economics: The similarities and differences
affiliations: University of Delhi

detail.title: Econometrics vs. Economics: The similarities and differences
detail.abstract: This review explores the relationship between economics and econometrics, highlighting their similarities and differences. Economics provides theoretical frameworks for understanding production, distribution, and consumption, while econometrics applies statistical and mathematical tools to test theories and analyze real-world data. The paper traces the evolution of econometrics, key terms, methods, applications, software integration, limitations, and future scope, emphasizing its growing role in policy-making, business strategy, and research through data-driven, evidence-based analysis.

title: Economic Inequality, Clientelism, and Public Service Provision in Africa
affiliations: George Washington University and IE University

detail.title: Economic Inequality, Clientelism, and Public Service Provision in Africa
detail.abstract: What shapes the prevalence of clientelism? Low income countries show a surprising amount of variation in this regard, suggesting determinants beyond poverty. In some relatively poor countries there is little clientelism, while in others clientelism persists even as they develop. We argue that economic inequality explains much of this variation because it shapes the tradeoff between targeted electoral strategies, such as vote-buying, and more broadly-based public service provision. We argue that inequality shapes the distribution of voter preferences regarding public services, which impacts the decision of elites to supply public services. This results in more vote-buying where inequality is higher. We use Afrobarometer data to test empirical implications of the theory.

title: Assessing the Influence of Immigration on Domestic Music Markets in France
affiliations: Université de Caen

detail.title: Assessing the Influence of Immigration on Domestic Music Markets in France
detail.abstract: This paper examines the influence of immigration on France's domestic music market between 2014 and 2013. Using a panel dataset combining national music revenue with regionally disaggregated immigration flows, we estimate fixed effects and difference-indifferences models to assess both structural associations and policy impacts. We find that while immigration is positively correlated with music revenue, this relationship weakens and becomes statistically insignificant once controls for digital adoption and cultural infrastructure are introduced. Moreover, the 2016 Talent Passport visa reform had no measurable effect on revenue trends. Our findings suggest that immigration signals broader cultural and digital shifts rather than directly driving economic outcomes. The results highlight the importance of cultural policy and infrastructure over short-term migration shocks in shaping creative industry performance.

detail.abstract: This study explores the impact of stock market development on economic growth in Nepal, covering data from 1994 to 2022. Using the Autoregressive Distributed Lag (ARDL) approach, the analysis confirms a significant long-term relationship between key stock market variables-particularly paid-up capital and the number of listed companies-and Gross Domestic Product (GDP). These findings highlight the crucial role of capital accumulation and market expansion in promoting sustained economic growth. In contrast, variables such as market capitalization, turnover, and government education expenditure showed limited or no significant influence on Nepal's economic growth in the long run. The short-run analysis revealed that real market capitalization has a significant but negative effect on GDP, while turnover was insignificant, indicating that short-term market fluctuations may not directly support economic development. Diagnostic tests confirmed the robustness and stability of the econometric model, while Granger causality tests indicated both bidirectional and unidirectional causal relationships between stock market indicators and economic growth. Based on these findings, the study recommends policy interventions focused on strengthening capital formation, promoting market listings and investor participation, improving market efficiency and investor protection, integrating financial and human capital development, and enhancing financial infrastructure and institutional frameworks. By implementing these policies, Nepal can better harness its stock market as a driver of inclusive and sustainable economic growth.

title: Is Love Blind? AI-Powered Trading with Emotional Dividends
affiliations: London Business School, Yuan Ze University and National University of Singapore (NUS)

detail.title: Is Love Blind? AI-Powered Trading with Emotional Dividends
detail.abstract: This study exploits the non-fungible token (NFT) setting to estimate the value of non-pecuniary benefits, a longstanding empirical challenge in private-value markets such as art, antiques, and other collectibles. After developing and validating our emotional dividend proxy (LOVE), we apply deep learning algorithms and discover that contemporaneous price fluctuations, certain collection features, and ownership wealth significantly contribute to its formation. Leveraging these parameters, we employ AI-powered models to estimate NFT prices with high accuracy, but find their predictive ability is decreasing in LOVE. Additionally, we demonstrate that LOVE-driven trading results in long-term financial losses for the average investor, highlighting a trade-off between wealth and emotional utility. Our study provides novel economic insights into the factors shaping emotional dividends and their role in the pricing of private-value assets. It also surfaces the limitations AI faces in emotionally charged markets, revealing new challenges for algorithmic trading when assets carry significant emotional utility.

title: Inflation Expectations and Risk Preferences
affiliations: Leibniz University Hannover, Leibniz  Universität Hannover and Leibniz University Hannover

detail.title: Inflation Expectations and Risk Preferences
detail.abstract: Risk preferences may influence how individuals interpret inflation information, but evidence is mixed due to endogeneity challenges. We show that risk-averse households and experts systematically report higher prior inflation expectations. In a survey randomized control trial (RCT), providing inflation forecast information significantly narrows this expectation gap. Our findings align with a framework where risk-averse agents deliberately overestimate inflation to maximize future utility. This bias is linked to physical information avoidance—actively avoiding information—rather than misprocessing it. These results highlight a behavioral channel through which risk aversion shapes inflation expectations, contributing to persistent expectation gaps across risk profiles.

title: Outer Retinal Bands Segmentation in Healthy Subjects: Comparative Study between Human and Deep Convolutional Neural Networks
affiliations: affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN, affiliation not provided to SSRN and affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: Outer Retinal Bands Segmentation in Healthy Subjects: Comparative Study between Human and Deep Convolutional Neural Networks
detail.abstract: Background To investigate different strategies for segmenting the outer retinal bands (ORBs) in spectral-domain optical coherence tomography (SD-OCT) images. Methods Cross-sectional observational study based on foveal-centered SD-OCT scans of healthy participants. Manual segmentation of the second hyperreflective band (Band 2), the third and fourth hyperreflective bands (Band 3+4) and photoreceptor outer segments (POS) was performed by two trained graders using onboard OCT software. Reproducibility was assessed using the intraclass and interclass correlation coefficient (ICC). Human annotations were used to train different Deep Convolutional Neural Network (dCNN) pretrained with a Sparse masked modelling on unlabelled data. The performance of the dCNNs was evaluated using dice score and pixel difference analyzes. Results One hundred eyes of healthy subjects were included. The intraclass correlation values were 0.737 (0.689; 0.779), 0.830 (0.795; 0.860) and 0.878 (0.852; 0.900), and the interclass correlation coefficients were 0.104 (-0.049; 0.253), 0.810 (0.740; 0.862) and 0.752 (0.678; 0.812) for Band 2, Band 3+4 and POS, respectively. From the DCNN, DRUNET showed the best performance: 91.6% for Band 2, 92.4% for Band 3+4 and 91.0% for POS. Pixel difference analysis between DRUNET and Grader 1 showed a deviation of 0.89 ± 0.44. Conclusions Manual segmentation of ORBs showed high repeatability, although segmentation of band 2 showed very low reproducibility. DRUNET outperformed other dCNN architectures, showing great potential to reduce inter-observer variability.

title: Does Search Engine Visibility Help ETFs Attract Flows?
affiliations: Stockholm School of Economics

detail.title: Does Search Engine Visibility Help ETFs Attract Flows?
detail.abstract: I use a unique web analytics dataset to study online activities of exchange-traded funds (ETFs) and propose a novel methodology to characterize these activities. Even after controlling for conventional factors as well as variations in product and consumer characteristics, I find that ETF issuers compete with each other in online space and gain an advantage in attracting flows through search engine marketing and improved online visibility. Better visibility of financial products, as proxied by their average rank on search engine result pages, helps to attract more capital flows, especially when products are listed on pages with high pay-per-click ad auctions.

title: Adaptation through Experience or Description? Evidence from an Experiment on Efficient Coding
affiliations: University of Southern California - Marshall School of Business and SC Johnson College of Business, Cornell University

detail.title: Adaptation through Experience or Description? Evidence from an Experiment on Efficient Coding
detail.abstract: The principle of efficient coding implies that the perception of monetary payoffs is shaped by the decision maker's prior beliefs. Specifically, payoffs that the decision maker expects to encounter more frequently should be perceived more accurately. Most previous tests of efficient coding rely on the decision maker's experience to shape the prior. We conduct a pre-registered experiment to test whether descriptive information about the prior affects behavior in a manner consistent with efficient coding. We randomize whether participants receive this information before the experiment begins. We find strong evidence for efficient coding; however, we detect no effect of information provision on behavior. Our results are consistent with the hypothesis that experience quickly crowds out any effect of descriptive information on optimal allocation of coding resources.

title: Prices Versus Quantities Revisited: The Case of a Transboundary Stock Pollutant
affiliations: Swarthmore College and affiliation not provided to SSRN

detail.title: Prices Versus Quantities Revisited: The Case of a Transboundary Stock Pollutant
detail.abstract: We study the relative merits of price versus quantity instruments in a dynamic model with two economies facing a transboundary stock pollutant like CO2. The climate policy debate has emphasized the importance of the relative slopes of marginal damages and abatement costs for ranking taxes versus cap and trade under technological uncertainty. It finds that taxes dominate quotas as the social cost of carbon curve is extremely flat. Our model features persistent cost shocks that generate perfectly correlated shifts of these two curves; these are as important to the ranking as is the slope ratio. Gradual diffusion of innovations generally favors quotas by changing the relative shifts. A larger size of an economy relative to the other also tends to favor quotas.
